p.s: In the newspaper article Language learning in the UK: can't, won't, don't John Worne states his point of view and uses communicative strategies, use of language and stylistic devices, which will be analyzed in the following.
First of all we look at the quality of the paper.
John Worne uses elevated language and complicated sentence structure.
He mostly backs his opinion up with evidence and sometimes uses colloquial language.
But overall I would say that The Telegraph is a quality paper.

Regarding the use of language John Worne uses inclusive language, due to the pronouns we, us and our (cf. l. 5) this includes the reader and he feels like he is part of the problem but can also be the solution.
To make his point of view clear he also uses persuasive techniques and stylistic devices.
The beginning of his first sentence, which is also his headline is an enumeration end it stresses his claim that the national view on learning foreign languages is disastrous (cf. l. 1).
In order to show that it is a country wide problem he uses the metaphor collective brains (cf. l. 5) which paints a picture for the reader.
Another metaphor can be found in line seven, where he says there is a long haul ahead.
Which basically means that there is a long way to go.
John Worne uses a comparison, to present his evidence.
He compares number of examesexams from years before (cf. ll. 9-11), that showcases the reader how the situation got worse and worse.
Leading to him considering to stop this trend.
Furthermore he is very ironic (cf. ll. 12-13), where he gives his opinion without evidence and uses very colloquial language.
He does that to convince the reader of how ridiculous the opposite is.
Moreover this use of language allows him to get a wider readership.
Another stylistic device are the Repetitionsrepetitions he uses (cf. ll. 27-29), they emphasise his points, like how it is easier to be a lawyer who can speak a foreign language.
To come to an end John Worne does an excellent job of attracting a big readership and convincing them to be on his side.
As he uses inclusive language stresses his points and turns the opposing side into a joke with well-chosen stylistic devices.
